name: Emon Roy Bappy
headline: Research and Development Engineer
summary:
Currently, I am a Research and Development Engineer at Cybernetics Hi-Tech Solutions (Pvt.) Ltd. where I am focused on the development and analysis of military robots for Bangladesh Army. Our team has already delivered two Explosive Ordinance Disposal Remotely Operated Vehicles (EOD-ROVs), which have been deployed in United Nations Peacekeeping Missions. Currently, I am working on a Man-Portable EOD ROV project along with my teammates. My key responsibilities include Design for Manufacturing and Assembly (DfMA), stress analysis, structural topology optimization, additive manufacturing methods for prototyping like Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM), molding of soft materials like silicone, subtractive manufacturing like CNC milling and Electro Discharge Machining (EDM). Recently, we have started working on composite materials. For the first time in Bangladesh’s history, we successfully implemented the resin infusion method to manufacture structural components using carbon fiber, achieving an industrial-grade solution within our own composite fabrication lab. This milestone not only demonstrates our manufacturing capabilities and knowledge but also creates a precedent for the country’s manufacturing infrastructure. 
 During my undergraduate studies in Mechanical Engineering at Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology (BUET), I built a strong foundation in electromechanical systems, computer-aided design, PCB design, and finite element analysis, which naturally pushed me to explore the intersection of robotics and manufacturing. As a third-year student in the mechanical department, I collaborated with my team to develop a bio-inspired soft robotic fish and a mechanical solution for variable capacity cooling tower. During my undergraduate thesis, I designed and fabricated a soft robotic actuator to replace the conventional rigid actuator in the medical robots used for Minimally Invasive Surgery (MIS). The soft actuator has three degrees of freedom to reach any area at the time of surgery, minimizing the number of incisions and reducing patient’s recovery time. 
 My goal is to pursue cutting-edge research that bridges the robotics field and manufacturing methods, ultimately contributing to the development of resilient and intelligent manufacturing solutions for humanitarian applications.

projects.title: Man-portable EOD-ROV
projects.description: Currently, we are developing a man-portable EOD ROV based on our experience of previously developed medium platform EOD ROV, Jontro Soinik v2.0. Initially, we analyzed the limitations of previous robot and new challenges to develop a small platform robot. In the first phase, we worked...
projects.longDescription:
Currently, we are developing a man-portable EOD ROV based on our experience of previously developed medium platform EOD ROV, Jontro Soinik v2.0. Initially, we analyzed the limitations of previous robot and new challenges to develop a small platform robot. In the first phase, we worked on building a lightweight structure keeping the strength of the structure maximum, maintaining a lower height of center of gravity, a new degree of freedom in arm- screw based telescopic beam. We are also implementing carbon fiber parts into the robot. These parts are made through resin infusion method, compression mold, hand layup within our composite fabrication lab.
 Based on our previous experience gained from developing a medium-platform EOD ROV, Jontro Soinik v2.0, our team is currently working on the design and fabrication of a man-portable EOD ROV. This initiative addresses the evolving operational requirements of field deployment, particularly in a constrained and high-risk environment like explosive materials. We started with a comprehensive analysis of the limitations observed in the previous platform and the alternative solution to overcome the limitations, alongside the unique challenges posed by miniaturizing the system without compromising functionality or durability. In the initial phase, our focus has been on engineering a lightweight yet structurally robust chassis, optimizing the center of gravity for enhanced stability, and introducing a novel degree of freedom in the manipulator arm through a screw-based telescopic beam mechanism. To further reduce weight and improve mechanical performance, we are integrating carbon fiber components into the robot’s architecture. These parts are fabricated in-house using advanced composite manufacturing techniques, including resin infusion, compression molding, and hand layup, within our dedicated composite fabrication laboratory. This approach not only enhances the robot’s operational efficiency but also reflects our commitment to pioneering indigenous solutions in high-performance robotics and materials engineering.

iterations: Thickened high‑stress links and reduced mass on low‑stress members
Material change to stainless on select brackets with low fatigue margins
Fillet optimization to reduce stress concentrations
Reinforced mounting points; verified bolt patterns
outcomes: FoS ≥ 5 achieved across critical load cases

projects.title: Jontro Soinik
projects.description: Jontro Soinik 1.0 (JS1.0) is Bangladesh’s third generation and most advanced indigenously developed Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) ...
projects.longDescription:
**Jontro Soinik 1.0** (JS1.0) is Bangladesh’s third generation and most advanced indigenously developed Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV) with environmental adaptability and disrupter firing capacity, which is first of it’s kind, engineered for rapid deployment and rugged performance in high-risk environments. Successfully tested by the Bangladesh Army, including live disrupter firing and IP55 water protection trials, it proves its readiness for real-world missions. Equipped with advanced electronics like GPS, thermal imaging, IR night vision, 4x optical zoom, and a 2MP camera system, it supports precision surveillance and remote neutralization of threats. With robust mechanical capabilities—stair climbing, slope handling (up to 40°), 360° claw rotation, 40kg grip force, and a lifting capacity of up to 20kg—the ROV is built for maneuverability and strength. Its 16Ah battery enables extended operations with active/passive overload protection, self-diagnostics, and fast recharging. Designed for battlefield reliability, **Jontro Soinik 1.0** embodies innovation, adaptability, and national pride in defense technology. 
 Jontro Soinik 1.0 is set for deployment in 2025 under the UN Peacekeeping Mission in the Republic of the Congo.

highlights: Developing a man‑portable EOD ROV with 7 DoF robotic arm for military applications.
Analyzed the performance of fixed‑wing UAVs and multirotor drones designed to carry high payloads of up to 50 kg.
Acquired hands‑on experience in CNC machining, fused deposition modeling, composite manufacturing, and molding.
Engineered an ROV with a 6 DoF arm, meticulously designed to operate and sustain functionality in harsh and challenging environments, ensuring robustness and reliability
Verified the structural integrity of the mechanical designs of an ROV through finite element analysis (FEA), identifying potential stress points and weaknesses
Acquired comprehensive knowledge of the three‑wheeler manufacturing process, encompassing welding, painting, and assembly sections
Developed a thorough understanding of industrial automation processes and the application of industrial robotic arms
Conducted a detailed analysis to identify and recommend improvements to make the manufacturing process more efficient
Built a Mars Rover capable of traversing through rocky terrain, collecting and processing specimens from the environment, and performingvarious tasks
Designed and implemented the PCB for the rover’s power distribution system, actuators, and sensors for onboard scientific experiment
Constructed a 6 DoF robotic arm from scratch, capable of holding a 5 kg payload in extended position
Contributed to the development of a competitive Formula Student automobile, taking part in the design, manufacturing, and experiments
Led the suspension team successfully, guiding the design and fabrication of critical components such as the upright, control arm, and bell crank

experience.description: Oversaw society activities and led the team.
